s.text: About 15 years ago, painter Chuck Close went out to Springs, Long Island, to meet Willem de Kooning, one of the greatest American artists of this century.
Asked a factual question, he was helpless, ignorant of the date, of where he lived.
About 15 years ago, painter Chuck Close went out to Springs, Long Island, to meet Willem de Kooning, one of the greatest American artists of this century.
About 15 years ago, painter Chuck Close went out to Springs, Long Island, to meet Willem de Kooning, one of the greatest American artists of this century.
About 15 years ago, painter Chuck Close went out to Springs, Long Island, to meet Willem de Kooning, one of the greatest American artists of this century.
The paintings from 1987 are full of charming facility, but their decorativeness is repetitive.
It bends, tilts, swells, enlarges, and shrinks in each new appearance, like a vacuum chamber full of snakes.
Asked a factual question, he was helpless, ignorant of the date, of where he lived.
One of my favorites among these paintings, Untitled V (1982), is built around a repeated shape that is like a dark letter "S."

His fat serpentine strokes and lacquer-smooth planes twisted around each other, arriving at exuberant new combinations that sometimes echoed his old friend Arshile Gorky as well as Henri Matisse and Piet Mondrian, painters whose final work was similarly buoyant.
The resulting swaths of color, like beach towels rippling on a laundry line, create a planar kind of abstraction, with large areas of smooth, erased whiteness.
The compositions become ever more undulating and graceful.
The compositions become ever more undulating and graceful.
Asked a factual question, he was helpless, ignorant of the date, of where he lived.
